body.p: The Salomon project uses the Subversion version control system. If you're new to Subversion, you can check out the online book about Subversion. Note that we are currently using Subversion 1.1.x (there are separate versions of the book covering 1.0 and 1.1).

section.name: Web Access to Subversion
section.p: If you just want to browse the source code, you can use the SVN View web interface to Subversion. This is current at all times.

section.name: Normal Subversion Access
section.P:
TO
URL to Salomons repository is: "svn+ssh://salomon.iisg.agh.edu.pl/home/svn/salomon/platform/trunk"
Console SVN:
if you have console svn client and you are familiar with cvs then there's nothing new for you here, just type the command:
svn co svn+ssh://salomon.iisg.agh.edu.pl/home/svn/salomon/platform/trunk -q --username [USERNAME]
[USERNAME] is four account name
GUI SVN client:
Come ON, There are many gui svn clients, I'm sure you can figure out how they work by your self or you don't need the source anyway, You have been given the URL for the repository and that's all you need ;P
As shown above
After you have downloaded the repository and made some (considerable and senseful) changes in it, its time to commit it back to the repository, the best way to do it is to type:
svn commit
in the directory of the source code, svn will check which files did you change and send them to the repository, but before you do that make sure that the source that you want to commit is compilable and there are no silly printouts or comments in it. You will be prompted for comment about your commit, write something about what you have changed (not to long ... just somethin meaningful like, "changed this , fixed that", this sort of stuff)
